description: Borrowed from Latin lūna (“moon; month; crescent”).

entries.meaning: (entomology) A luna moth: a member of species Actias luna.
examples: “Gee,” whispered Oliver. He sat there staring. “A luna! I never thought I’d see a real luna!”

entries.meaning: (Christianity, chiefly Catholicism and Anglicanism) A lunette: a crescent-shaped receptacle, often glass, for holding the (consecrated) host (the bread of communion) upright when exposed in the monstrance. [from 19th c.]
examples: The Bread of Angels is first taken from the tabernacle, where it rests in the luna, and placed upon the altar, covered with a corporal. After genuflecting, the priest puts the luna containing the Blessed Sacrament on its throne—the monstrance—and elevates it  […]

There are several reasons why the Hawaiian-born Japanese boys and girls do not take kindly to plantation labor, but one of the chief reasons is the objection to the kind of lunas  who oversee the work of the laborers.
